ygData.subject: Re: [cantera] Specified temp. too high for eq. calc. but kinetics works
ygData.msgSnippet: Yes, you may be able to do it.  Cantera does not catch every possible error that can be made... But I would strongly advise reviewing the high temperature

Content-Type: text/plain;
	charset=US-ASCII;
	delsp=yes;
	format=flowed

Yes, you may be able to do it.  Cantera does not catch every possible  
error that can be made... But I would strongly advise reviewing the  
high temperature thermo data for the species with fits that end at  
1500 K before believing the results either from equilibrium or by  
integrating rate equations...  Extrapolating these NASA-style  
polynomials outside the range for which they were fit can lead to  
very big errors, since the polynomial may have physically unrealistic  
behavior.


On Jan 17, 2007, at 8:01 AM, Anders Andreasen wrote:

> Dear Cantera users
>
> I am doing some calculations using the Leeds sulfur mechanism  
> extension (cantera 1.6 through python 2.4 on Red Hat Enterprise  
> Linux WS 4) including both equilibrium
> and kinetics calculations. If I try to equlibrate a gas phase  
> solution based on the this mechanism (with included thermodynamic  
> description) I get the following error
>
> ************************************************
>                 Cantera Error!
> ************************************************
> Procedure: ChemEquil
> Error:   Specified temperature ( 1971.65 K) outside valid range of  
> 300 K to 1500 K
>
> This of course expected behaviour since some of the species  
> thermodynamic parameters are only given up to 1500 K.
> However, I can still integrate the rate equations (see code below -  
> the description of the composition of the SOx gas has been left out  
> in this mail)
>
> soxgas=Cantera.importPhase('SOx.cti')
> soxgas.setTemperature(2000)
> tnow = 0.
> tfinal = self.dt
> reactor = Reactor.Reactor(contents = sox, name = 'reactor1', energy  
> = 'off')
> reactor_net = Reactor.ReactorNet([reactor])
> while tnow < tfinal:
> tnow = reactor_net.step(tfinal)
> reactor_net.reactors()[0].syncContents()
>
> In the ctml file all reactions are listed as being reversible.
> I have the impression that the reverse reaction rate is calculated  
> as the forward reaction rate constant divided by the equilibrium  
> constant i.e.k_f/K_eq.
> What puzzles me here is the fact that. while not being able to do  
> equilibration, it is still possible to calculate the equilibrium  
> constant (which I guess is calculated with NASA coefficients from  
> the cti/xml file)..
>
> I would very much appreciate any input on this topic
>
> Kind regards
>
> 


--Apple-Mail-10--377312003
Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable
Content-Type: text/html;
	charset=ISO-8859-1
